elements.name: ApplicantNeedsProtection
elements.title: Do you, {ApplicantName}, need to be included on a `Protection Order` against {RespondentName}?
elements.description: A Protection Order is a list of conditions set by a judge that your ex-partner must follow. This usually means no visits to your home or workplace, no phone calls, emails, or letters, and no messages through a friend or relative.

elements.description: An open file could mean that documents have been filed at the courthouse but a judge may not have made an order yet.

elements.name: ExistingFamilyCaseFAQ
elements.title: If I have a family law file open in the Supreme Court of British Columbia, should I include that?
elements.body: No, the file numbers are different between Provincial and Supreme Court. If you already have a Provincial Court file number, you will want to make sure that this document gets filed with the same file number.

elements.name: ErrorNeitherGuardians
elements.title:
This service is currently limited to situations where ex-partners have shared children. These children cannot have parents or guardians other than you, {ApplicantName}, and {RespondentName}.

If any children have parents or guardians other than you and {RespondentName}, you can still apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Protection Order. Click here for Provincial Court Family Forms.

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

templateElements.title:
Who are {panel.ChildName}'s Guardians?

A guardian is someone who is legally allowed to make decisions for a child under the age of 19.

A biological parent is not automatically a guardian. A parent who has lived with {panel.ChildName} or regularly cares for {panel.ChildName} is a guardian. This parent is still a guardian even after they stop living with the {panel.ChildName}.

A parent can be added or removed as a guardian by the court or by agreement between the parents.

Click here for more information about who is a guardian.

templateElements.title:
Who makes Parenting Decisions for {panel.ChildName}?

Parenting decisions are also know as parenting responsibilities. These responsibilities include:
  • making daily decisions about the child
  • making decisions about your child's education and religious upbringing
  • signing consent forms including healthcare treatments, and
  • applying for passports

elements.name: NoContactRespondentSummary
elements.title:
If the judge decides to make your `Protection Order`, {RespondentName} will be ordered to stay away from you and/or your children. If {RespondentName} doesn't follow the Protection Order, they may face criminal charges.

The following questions will guide you to personalize your safety needs for your Protection Order.

elements.name: ExplanationDoneMainForm
elements.title:
Normally, applying for a Protection Order means that {RespondentName} will get notified and they will get time to respond.

A judge can decide to change the amount of time {RespondentName} has to respond.

A judge can also decide to review your application without {RespondentName} being notified until after the Protection Order is made.

elements.name: PORSpeedup
elements.title: Normally, {RespondentName} will get 30 days to file a reply. Do you need this Protection Order to be made sooner?

elements.name: PORNoNotice
elements.title:
Normally, a judge will want to hear from you, {ApplicantName} and {RespondentName} before making a decision.

Do you want a judge to make their decision before {RespondentName} gets to tell their story?
elements.description: If a judge makes a Protection Order without {RespondentName} getting to tell their story, {RespondentName} will still get a fair chance after to ask a judge to change or cancel the Protection Order.

elements.name: PORSpeedNormalAffidavit
elements.title: Do you, {ApplicantName}, want to use this service to write an `affidavit`?
elements.description:
An affidavit is one of the ways you will tell your story to the court. Most judges will require that you write an affidavit, but others may not.

A judge may also ask you to tell your story, under oath, in court.

elements.name: ExplanationPORSpeedNormalAffidavit
elements.title:
Most judges will require that you write an affidavit. If you do not want to use this service to write an affidavit, you have other options:
  • Click here for the PDF form
  • Get a paper form at a courthouse registry. Click here for a list of courthouse locations
  • Get a lawyer to help you write one

elements.name: ExplanationPORSpeedup
elements.title: A judge will need a reason why you need this Protection Order sooner. There are more questions you'll need to answer in this service.

elements.name: ExplanationPORNoNotice
elements.title:
A judge will need a reason why they should hear your story without hearing {RespondentName}'s story. There are more questions you'll need to answer in this service.

There will also be a paper form to fill out at the court registry. This paper form will help the judge make a Protection Order that is personalized to your safety needs. You should not need any additional information to complete this form.

elements.name: PORWhatHappened
elements.visibleIf: {PORSpeedNormalAffidavit} = 'y' or ({PORSpeedup} = 'y' and {PORNoNotice} notempty) or ({PORSpeedup} notempty and {PORNoNotice} = 'y')
elements.title: Describe your relationship history with {RespondentName} and what {RespondentName} has done to make you and your family feel unsafe?
elements.description:
Tell your story in your own words. Include all the facts that you think the judge may need.

Everything you say must to be true to the best of your knoweldge.

You can include information that you got from someone else, but you must include who told you, when they told you and that you believe what they said is true. For example, you can include information that your child has told you.

Click here to get tips for writing your affidavit

Click here to get a list of information to include in your affidavit
